articles.headline: Sinwar’s Death Was a Victory for Israel. But Can the U.S. Persuade It to ‘Take the Win’?
articles.snippet: Assassinating Yahya Sinwar was Israel’s Osama bin Laden moment. But getting a cease-fire deal done in the last three months of the Biden presidency is a much bigger reach.
articles.abstract: Assassinating Yahya Sinwar was Israel’s Osama bin Laden moment. But getting a cease-fire deal done in the last three months of the Biden presidency is a much bigger reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within hours of the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar on Thursday, President Biden and his aides scrambled to design one last push for a broad de-escalation of violence in the Middle East: a cease-fire and hostage deal in Gaza, a pullback from Israeli attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon, a confident declaration of victory by Israel that might allow it to forgo a major retaliation against Iran.

articles.headline: Sinwar’s Final Moments: On the Run, Hurt, Alone, but Still Defiant
articles.snippet: Israeli forces had been steadily closing in on Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader, for weeks before he was cornered and killed in a ruined house in the Gaza Strip.
articles.abstract: Israeli forces had been steadily closing in on Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader, for weeks before he was cornered and killed in a ruined house in the Gaza Strip.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end, the fearsome militant leader who had helped unleash a vicious war seemed barely a threat.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: The Powerful Companies Driving Local Drugstores Out of Business
articles.snippet: The biggest pharmacy benefit managers are profiting by systematically underpaying independent drugstores, creating “pharmacy deserts” across the country.
articles.abstract: The biggest pharmacy benefit managers are profiting by systematically underpaying independent drugstores, creating “pharmacy deserts” across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The small-town drugstore closed for the last time on a clear and chilly afternoon in February. Jon Jacobs, who owned Yough Valley Pharmacy, hugged his employees goodbye. He cleared the shelves and packed pill bottles into plastic bins.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: Welcome to the Era of the $20,000 Family Car Insurance Bill
articles.snippet: Have several children, a driveway full of cars and a few moving violations? Good luck to you. There are some ways to lessen the financial pain.
articles.abstract: Have several children, a driveway full of cars and a few moving violations? Good luck to you. There are some ways to lessen the financial pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re 16 years old, live in California and just passed your driver’s license test, the first thing you should do is drive your family to In-N-Out Burger for a milkshake and some animal-style fries.

articles.headline: Trump Thinks the Border Got Him Elected in 2016. He’s Convinced It Will Do So Again.
articles.snippet: Voters rank the economy and high cost of living as their top issue. Donald J. Trump believes immigration “beats out the economy,” and he’s made it his closing message.
articles.abstract: Voters rank the economy and high cost of living as their top issue. Donald J. Trump believes immigration “beats out the economy,” and he’s made it his closing message.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump turned his back to the crowd and stared up at the screen. Ominous music rang out. For the next minute and a half, the former president and his audience in Atlanta stood and silently watched clips of news reports of undocumented immigrants committing horrific crimes.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Halloween’s Mutation: From Humble Holiday to Retail Monstrosity
articles.snippet: Americans once made their own costumes and candy. Now, the holiday has rapidly commercialized, transforming into an economic juggernaut.
articles.abstract: Americans once made their own costumes and candy. Now, the holiday has rapidly commercialized, transforming into an economic juggernaut.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 1, 1876, The New York Times declared Halloween “departed,” destined for the grave.

articles.headline: Jill Stein Won’t Stop. No Matter Who Asks.
articles.snippet: People in Stein’s life have implored her to abandon her bid for president, lest she throw the election to Donald Trump. She’s on the ballot in almost every critical state.
articles.abstract: People in Stein’s life have implored her to abandon her bid for president, lest she throw the election to Donald Trump. She’s on the ballot in almost every critical state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jill Stein, the Green Party’s serial presidential candidate, has heard the pleading from strangers.

articles.headline: U.S. Agencies Fund, and Fight With, Elon Musk. A Trump Presidency Could Give Him Power Over Them.
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk, who holds billions in federal contracts, wants to be in charge of the regulators that oversee him if Donald Trump wins.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk, who holds billions in federal contracts, wants to be in charge of the regulators that oversee him if Donald Trump wins.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s influence over the federal government is extraordinary, and extraordinarily lucrative.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, David A. Fahrenthold, Aaron Krolik and Kirsten Grind

articles.headline: Door-Knocks, Texts, and Ads, Ads, Ads: Life on the Swing-State Battlefield
articles.snippet: This year’s campaign offers a vivid reminder of how much the playing field in presidential elections has shrunk, giving voters in a handful of states a disproportionate influence in the decision.
articles.abstract: This year’s campaign offers a vivid reminder of how much the playing field in presidential elections has shrunk, giving voters in a handful of states a disproportionate influence in the decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electronic billboards along Route 22 in eastern Pennsylvania, usually a flickering procession of ads for car dealerships, are now flashing images of Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump. Billboards along Interstate 94 near Milwaukee feature Republican ads blaming Ms. Harris for rising prices.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Alan Blinder, Julie Bosman, Benjamin Oreskes, Mitch Smith and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: He Dreamed of Escaping Gaza. The World Watched Him Burned Alive.
articles.snippet: A video of Shaaban al-Dalou burning to death after an Israeli strike at a hospital has stoked criticism from Israel’s allies and highlighted the plight of people trapped in Gaza.
articles.abstract: A video of Shaaban al-Dalou burning to death after an Israeli strike at a hospital has stoked criticism from Israel’s allies and highlighted the plight of people trapped in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.
articles.byline: By Bilal Shbair and Erika Solomon

articles.headline: For Trump, a Lifetime of Scandals Heads Toward a Moment of Judgment
articles.snippet: No major party presidential candidate, much less president, in American history has been accused of wrongdoing so many times.
articles.abstract: No major party presidential candidate, much less president, in American history has been accused of wrongdoing so many times.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the history of the 2024 election is written, one of the iconic images illustrating it will surely be the mug shot taken of Donald J. Trump after one of his four indictments, staring into the camera with his signature glare. It is an image not of shame but of defiance, the image of a man who would be a convicted felon before Election Day and yet possibly president of the United States again afterward.

articles.headline: Starring in Kamala Harris’s Closing Argument: Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris has made a notable shift in strategy to paint Donald Trump as unfit and dangerous as Democrats grow anxious about the closeness of the race just two weeks out.
articles.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has made a notable shift in strategy to paint Donald Trump as unfit and dangerous as Democrats grow anxious about the closeness of the race just two weeks out.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the presidential race a dead heat two weeks before Election Day, Vice President Kamala Harris is moving aggressively to make sure voters in the battlegrounds remember precisely why they rejected Donald J. Trump four years ago.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood, Lisa Lerer and Michael Gold

articles.headline: How a TV Hit Sparked Debate About Having Too Many Babies
articles.snippet: The Sani family in northern Nigeria has six children, more than the parents can afford but fewer than their own parents had. Birthrates, and the decisions couples make about family size, are changing across Africa.
articles.abstract: The Sani family in northern Nigeria has six children, more than the parents can afford but fewer than their own parents had. Birthrates, and the decisions couples make about family size, are changing across Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five young sisters and their brother crowded around a small television in their modest cement house, a wriggling, giggling pile of skinny limbs and abandoned homework. Like families across northern Nigeria, the Sani family had been waiting all week for Thursday night to watch the latest episode of their favorite show, a comedy drama called “Gidan Badamasi.”
articles.byline: By Ruth Maclean and Yagazie Emezi

articles.headline: Trump Ratchets Up Threats on the Media
articles.snippet: Presidents are not all-powerful, but, if elected, Donald Trump would have some influence with the federal regulators who oversee major television networks.
articles.abstract: Presidents are not all-powerful, but, if elected, Donald Trump would have some influence with the federal regulators who oversee major television networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Threatening the news media is nothing new for former President Donald J. Trump. He has accused major news outlets of defamation, blocked journalists from rallies and White House events, goaded followers into profane chants about CNN and popularized the term “fake news,” now embraced by autocrats around the world.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and David McCabe

articles.headline: Why Chinese Are Rushing Into a ‘Casino’ Stock Market
articles.snippet: Steps to bolster the economy have set off a stock buying frenzy. Our columnist spoke to Chinese investors about why they are jumping in knowing the risks.
articles.abstract: Steps to bolster the economy have set off a stock buying frenzy. Our columnist spoke to Chinese investors about why they are jumping in knowing the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: They call China’s stock market a “casino,” yet they are rushing in. They are betting money that the government really does want to finally crawl out of the hole it has dug. They are speculating, looking for short-term gains, with a great degree of uneasiness.

articles.headline: Inside the Last-Ditch Hunt by Harris and Trump for Undecided Voters
articles.snippet: Both campaigns are digging through troves of data to find these crucial Americans. They both think many are younger, Black or Latino. The Harris team is also eyeing white, college-educated women.
articles.abstract: Both campaigns are digging through troves of data to find these crucial Americans. They both think many are younger, Black or Latino. The Harris team is also eyeing white, college-educated women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are carrying out a virtual house-to-house hunt for the final few voters who are still up for grabs, guided by months of painstaking research about these elusive Americans.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Meet the Florida Billionaire Who Wants to Be a Newspaper Baron
articles.snippet: David Hoffmann has already bought 5 percent of one of America’s largest newspaper companies. Now, he wants to control the whole thing.
articles.abstract: David Hoffmann has already bought 5 percent of one of America’s largest newspaper companies. Now, he wants to control the whole thing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The newspaper industry has decayed so much in recent years that even Warren Buffett — the world-famous investor whose annual meetings have included a newspaper toss — has declared the business “toast.”

articles.headline: As Trump Served Up McDonald’s Fries, Vitriol Boiled Outside
articles.snippet: In Pennsylvania, a critical swing state, supporters of Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, some in weird costumes, gathered along a roadside and screamed at one another.
articles.abstract: In Pennsylvania, a critical swing state, supporters of Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, some in weird costumes, gathered along a roadside and screamed at one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, former President Donald J. Trump dropped by a McDonald’s in Bucks County, Pa. He had cooked up a stunt to troll Vice President Kamala Harris, who has talked about having worked at McDonald’s one summer during college. Inside the restaurant, Mr. Trump wore an apron and dropped French fries into a vat of gurgling oil. Across the street, something much unhealthier was bubbling up.

articles.headline: ‘Monotonous and Filthy’: Paul Whelan’s Life in a Russian Prison
articles.snippet: The former U.S. Marine describes the moment of his arrest and the long years waiting for his release.
articles.abstract: The former U.S. Marine describes the moment of his arrest and the long years waiting for his release.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Whelan was in Moscow that day at the storied Metropole Hotel, getting ready for the wedding of a fellow U.S. Marine, when a longtime Russian friend, a junior officer in the frontier guards, dropped by unexpectedly.
